reviewText:
Got a free copy of the game from orlygift.com

I have been playing Magic the garthering and other trading cards for over 20 years now...
This is honstly not a bad trading card game.
But like hundreds different type of trading cards that fail every year this one also have some fatal flaws.

1. There is not enough player. (this is also the killing facter for most failed trading card games.)
The game server is a ghost town and i waited whole 10 min and no one has come online to play. And this is during orlygift giveaway so there should be people around to try out the game.

2. The interface is bad... It's too tight together with small fonts and the fonts color are bad contrast to the back ground.
It's kinda make my eyes bleed looking at it.

3. Above 2 is quite enough.. Even through there are other small flaws such as confusing tutorial mission..

I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone because it's a failed project.
It's got good concept but lack solid money to promot it. It also lack even careful development for better interface and explaination...

You end up playing the same AI computer over and over to very slowly get cards to improve your deck instead of playing against humans.

4/10 would be my final rating... unless by a great miracle that they make a TV or Cartoon for it.. It's a failed Trading card game like many many others...
voteText: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
*FULL DISCLOSURE* I won a key for this game from orlygift.com

I want to like Nanofights. I really do.
Collectible Card Games have a special place in my cold, black, gamer heart. Nanofights, however, is missing much of what makes a CCG fun and entertaining, you know, good.

Most of the card artwork is good. Some of it is very good, a few pieces of it are poor, and a handful are *ahem* closely resembling other copyrighted material (like the Ork Truck card for the Outlaws faction - Games Workshop™ might not appreciate that one).

Distressingly, there are several other areas where the game is simply mediocre to just plain bad.

The UI is atrocious. It functions, but it feels like a tacked on, overly-graphic layer sitting on top of a form page engineered for database calls, along with a chat window and players online (none to one, in my playtime). Organizing your deck isn't intuitive. The tools are there, but they aren't easy to use, and trying to see the cards you have without a lot of bulls**t getting in the way prevents you from building a new deck without a lot of time and hassle.

The gameplay is awful. The actual underlying cards and mechanics seem solid, if not tired and already done by better games (Mojang's Scrolls comes to mind). Again, the UI for card battles makes for an underwhelming and sometimes confusing experience. The sounds are terrible; I had to turn them off. Actual combat is resolved in turns too fast to see clearly what happened and why, meaning you really have to know all the cards in play and their effects and how they'll play out before turns end to grasp that round's results. If there was more substance and interesting effects going on, and slower turn resolution to allow you take in the round at a glance and enjoy it, the game would be much, much better.

In its current state, I simply cannot recommend Nanofights. The price tag is concerning, too. I didn't pay for my copy, but if I hadn't won a key from orlygift, I could have downloaded this game on my phone and played for free. And maybe on that platform, the game's flaws wouldn't have been such a letdown. On PC, though, they are far too glaring and distracting to allow for much enjoyment from this game for all but the most die-hard, IDGAF players of CCGs out there.

Game Score: 3 out of 10 Cosmic Dragons

reviewText: This is a card game in which you can battle against the computer or online players to achieve collecting different cards.  It's not well explained in the tutorial and has a bit of a learning curve, but eventually you start to get the hang of it.  I didn't find any matches online, so perhaps everyone is still trying to beat the computer. So far I won 1 out of 3 matches.

reviewText: You can feel it's a Java-based game when you touch the UI which looks so littery, also there is something wrong with click registration. Other than that it seems like a well thought out sci-fi universe card game, borrowing and blending together traits from different classical origins, surely the author put soul in the work. Still don't buy it if you're not especially into sci-fi & card games.\n\nСразу чувствуется, что это игра на Яве, как только прикасаешься к ее интерфейсу, такому перегруженному, у которого также какие-то нелады с регистрацией нажатий. В остальном это похоже на карточную игру в продуманной фантастической вселенной, где позаимствованы и слиты воедино черты из разных классических источников, автор явно вложил душу. Все же не стоит покупать, если вы не увлечены в особенности карточными играми про фантастику.

reviewText:
It's literally a free game, but for some reason they want to charge people for playing on PC?

The client itself is completely DRM free and is in no way whatsoever linked to your Steam account, nor even require Steam to be running/installed after you install Nanofights. You just make an account in the game client itself and have access to the full game with online play. I am not sure what kind of business model this is supposed to be exactly, here it is $9.99 and it is available free on other platforms/services.

Even if there are differences, (immoral) people could just zip up the game directory and pass it around to others ro play completely free anyway as, again, it's not tied to Steam at all.

Weird.
voteText: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It seems like fun and and it looks good after winning the 2nd tutorial match which I kind of get a gist of why some of the cards are unplaceable but only after losing the 1st match and after the explaining tutorial which does not explain much about the game. The battle aspect, placement is great for this kind of tactical card games. What turns me off is the control, buttons and overlay. It feels impossible to drag the card to the battlefield and requires several attempts. The buttons are hard to differentiate and trying to build a deck is impossible. My cards just suddenly disappear and clicking show all cards does not show any. Trying to read and get explaination from a card is impossible. I still do not understand what the crosshair means and whether a card has any other effect. Graphic is poor and ui is non intuitive. Overall it is a poorly made game and i was surprise that it uses java to launch the game.

reviewText:
Nanofights has some good game mechanics but they are lost in an overcrowded interface with text bleed.

I like the way battles work and the resouce and tech level game. However, it has a few of the problems that the HEROES of M&M card game has with battlefield movement and stalling.

other cons:
login to play / always online - but you are online all alone
very few cards in your collection when you start and you gain them very slowly

In the end there is very little content for the price tag...

reviewText: Nanofights is an “Online Trading Card Game”, made for fast gameplay. reviewText:
You only start with beginner's deck as usual, and you would need to register in their website to do online transaction for more cards and/or trade with other players, which i didn't register so i couldn't confirm on that.

The game itself is interesting, however, the tutorial doesn't teach you much and the server is basically empty. It is just you and the AI. With only 1 deck to play with, and only with the AI, it bores you down very fast.

It would be great if there are more players in the server to play with, so the card fights will be more interesting, witty and fun. Until then, i couldn't recommend anyone at this price point, even though i got this game for free...
